Investment Program  The Government of Pakistan (the Government) has requested the 
Description  Asian Development Bank (ADB) to support the Power Distribution 
  Enhancement Investment Program (the Investment Program) and 
provide financing through a multitranche financing facility (MFF) 
for $810 million over 10 years. This represents 15% of the total 
power  distribution  sector  investment  plan  for  2008–2017  of 
$5.2 billion.  The  MFF  has  a  maximum  utilization  period  of 
10 years,  and  the  periodic  financing  requests  (PFRs)  will  be 
converted into separate loans. 
 
The  Government  has  entered  into  a  framework  financing 
agreement  (FFA)  with  ADB  for  up  to  $810  million  through 
individual loans to finance the Investment Program in July 2008.  
 
In accordance with the FFA, the Government has submitted the 
first  PFR  to  ADB  in  an  amount  of  $242  million  from  ordinary 
capital  resources  (OCR)  and  in  an  amount  of  $10  million 
equivalent  in  special  drawings  rights  (SDR)  from  Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) resources. The first PFR for these two 
loans will be presented to ADB’s Board of Directors at the same 
time as this paper and the FFA. 
 
Sector Strategy  Pakistan’s power sector faces difficulties in its efforts to support 
the Government’s strategy of increasing the electricity supply to its 
urban  and  rural  population  and  of  securing  overall  economic 
growth. The key problems are (i) lack of generation capacity, (ii) 
increasing  constraints  in  the  transmission  and  distribution 
systems, (iii) weak financial management and sustainability of the 
sector  entities,  and  (iv)  inadequate  corporate  governance 
structures for the power companies.  
 
To support development of the power sector and to encourage 
private sector participation, the Government has approved power 
sector  policies,  strategies,  and  road  maps  to  (i)  ensure 
independent  regulation  of  the  power  sector;  (ii)  complete  the 
power sector unbundling of the Water and Power Development 
Authority  (WAPDA)  by  establishing  four  generation,  one 
transmission,  and  eight  distribution  companies;  (iii)  begin  the

ii   
power sector privatization program; and (iv) evaluate and optimize 
the fuel sources of the power sector to ensure energy security and 
minimize overall tariff requirements.  
 
Implementation of the Government’s power sector strategy would 
have  three  main  outcomes:  (i) sector  reforms  to  increase 
efficiencies  and  effectiveness  and  to  create  an  enabling 
environment for more private sector participation and investment; 
(ii) capacity building in all sector organizations, covering financial 
management,  efficiency  improvement,  the  clean  development 
mechanism, and project management; and (iii) completion of large 
infrastructure development projects in generation, transmission, 
and distribution. 
 
The  Investment  Program  is  closely  linked  to  Pakistan’s  power 
sector strategy and is an integral part of the power distribution 
development program. The Investment Program will enhance the 
efficiency of the overall power distribution system; and provide an 
adequate  and  reliable  power  supply  to  a  greater  number  of 
industrial, commercial, and residential customers.  
 
Sector Road Map   This Investment Program focuses on power distribution. In order 
  to enable the power to be effectively, reliably, and safely delivered 
  to existing and new customers, the power distribution companies 
  (DISCOs), in coordination with the Ministry of Water and Power 
  (MOWP), have prepared the Power Distribution Sector Road Map, 
  2008–2017. Based on current system demand and load growth 
  forecasts  in  each  region,  the  road  map  recommends  short- 
  (priority), medium-, and long-term system improvement projects 
  and details the investment needs.  
   
The objective of the road map is to show how the eight DISCOs 
 
can deliver reliable and high-quality power supply to the rising 
 
number  of  industrial,  commercial,  agricultural,  and  domestic 
 
customers.  It  is  consistent  with  the  Government’s  poverty 
 
reduction strategy and has the following intended outcomes: (i) a 
 
more efficient power system; (ii) high-quality power supply through 
 
a  more  reliable  and  stable  system;  (iii)  greater  geographic 
 
coverage; and (iv) greater availability of and access to affordable 
electricity, by relieving the power distribution constraints. 
 
The eight DISCOs were established as part of Pakistan’s power 
sector unbundling in 1999. Among them, they cover the whole of 
Pakistan, except areas serviced by the Karachi Electricity Supply 
Company, tribal areas, and the Northern Areas. Each DISCO is 
required  by  incorporation  and  by  regulatory  requirements  to 
(i) maintain and upgrade its current system; (ii) plan, design, and 
implement  system  expansion;  and  (iii) operate  the  system 
according to operational needs and distribution license conditions 
to ensure effective, reliable, and safe distribution of electricity from 
the  supply  points  to  customers’  premises  across  its  licensed 
territory.

iii

2017  is  estimated  at  $5.2  billion.  The  investments  consist  of 
improvements  to  the  secondary  transmission  grid  (STG), 
distribution  of  power  (DOP),  energy  loss  reduction  (ELR), 
capacitors,  and  miscellaneous  investments  to  the  distribution 
system.

  The immediate priority for investment in the distribution systems is 
to address the capacity shortfalls that currently result in regular 
system  outages  and  supply  interruptions  to  customers.  These 
works need to be done urgently to avoid rapid deterioration of 
power transformers which could result in prolonged outages and 
load shedding.  
 
Tranche-1  under  the  Investment  Program  will  cover  these 
identified  priorities  and  include  (i)  addition  of  circuit  and 
transformer capacity to enable the already overloaded systems to 
deliver  present  demand  reliably  and  meet  the  expected  load 
growth, (ii) loss reduction, and (iii) refurbishment of distribution 
networks.  Benefits  to  be  delivered  from  the  subprojects  in 
Tranche-1  include  addition  of  about  2,200  megavolt-amperes 
(MVA)  of  transformer  capacity,  improved  security  of  supply  to 
customers by moving toward compliance with regulatory security 
standards  governing  planning  and  operation  of  the  distribution 
system, and reliability improvements on the lower voltages.

Implementation Support  The  power  sector  entities,  specifically  the  DISCOs,  lack  the 
Component  required level and mix of skills or support systems necessary to 
operate  as  independent  entities  covering  the  whole  range  of 
electricity  business  requirements.  Improvements  to  corporate

iv   
governance and support systems are required.  
 
A  support  component  is  an  integral  part  of  the  proposed 
Investment Program. The total cost of the Investment Program’s 
support component is estimated at $10 million for the duration of 
the Investment Program. The objective of the component is to 
provide both resources and capacity to enable the DISCOs to 
improve  and  expand  their  current  project  preparation, 
implementation, and monitoring capabilities. Support activities will 
be  developed  to  cover  (i)  general  power  distribution  business 
management  including  project  implementation,  portfolio  review, 
project  management,  and  program  management;  (ii) technical 
operation  and  maintenance;  (iii)  accounting,  financial  and 
economic management, and financial reporting; (iv) contracting, 
procurement,  and  inventory  management;  (v)  a  management 
information  system  and  economics  of  cost  recovery  and  tariff 
setting;  and  (vi)  project  development,  including  policy 
development,  a  feasibility  study,  site  identification,  and  project 
design. 
 
Set of Representations  The Government has completed the legal unbundling of the power 
and Warranties  sector.  The  regulator,  the  National  Electric  Power  Regulatory 
Authority (NEPRA), determined distribution tariffs for each of the 
eight DISCOs in 2007. Timely submissions of tariff applications 
will be ensured and DISCOs’ financial and operational autonomy 
safeguarded. During implementation of the Investment Program, 
further improvements and refinements will be encouraged, and 
measures will be put in place to ensure further progress toward 
operational and financial autonomy.  
 
Investment Program  Power is an essential commodity for the economic and social 
Rationale  development  of  Pakistan.  Supply  of  reliable  electricity  to  all 
customers  throughout  the  country  raises  living  standards  and 
stimulates commercial and industrial growth. Historically, power 
generation  and  transmission  subsectors  have  received  more 
attention than distribution. Inadequate distribution of electricity has 
become a bottleneck, inhibiting economic growth and affecting all 
customers. The Investment Program will address this bottleneck 
and improve future performance, as well as increasing efficiency 
and effectiveness through technical and other improvements.  
 
Pakistan’s  power  sector  is  experiencing  severe  shortfalls  in 
meeting the country’s current electricity demand. The Government 
is implementing a series of the integrated activities in line with the 
power  sector  development  strategy  set  in  the  Medium Term 
Development Framework, 2005–2010 (MTDF) in May 2005. The 
MTDF envisages additional power generation, transmission, and 
distribution  capacities  to  ensure  sufficient  electricity  supply  to 
meet the projected 8% per annum growth in demand over the 
planning  period.  The  growth  in  demand  was  about  16%  in 
FY2007.

v
 
Power  generation  is  expected  to  grow  from  about 
19,540 megawatts (MW) in 2005 to 162,590 MW in 2030. ADB is 
actively  working  with  the  Government  and  private  power 
generation  developers  to  finance  public-  and  privately-owned 
generation stations to meet the current and future demand for 
electricity.  In  addition,  there  are  bottlenecks  in  the  power 
transmission  subsector.  To  facilitate  efficient  and  effective 
evacuation of power from existing and new power stations, the 
Government is implementing multiple activities in accordance with 
its Power Transmission Sector Road Map, 2007–2016. In 2006, at 
the  request  of  the  Government,  ADB  agreed  to  a  long-term 
financing arrangement to rehabilitate, augment, and expand the 
power transmission system; and allow power evacuation from the 
planned power stations in the least-cost power generation plan.  
 
Even with increased generation and improved transmission, there 
will be power shortages caused by distribution constraints. The 
distribution system suffers from high technical and commercial 
losses,  outdated  design,  and  poor  performance.  It  is  heavily 
loaded and in parts already overloaded, with high losses and poor 
reliability levels. Power shortages and customer disconnections 
are becoming much more regular and will worsen unless all power 
distribution elements  are  significantly  improved  urgently.  There 
remain significant investment requirements in the eight DISCOs to 
improve reliability and reduce losses alongside system extensions 
to unserved areas. In addition, the DISCOs need to observe the 
regulatory requirements, and environmental and social safeguard 
standards. 
 
Impact and Outcome  This  Investment  Program  will  (i)  improve  power  distribution 
infrastructure  through  system  rehabilitation,  augmentation,  and 
expansion;  and  relieve  the  power  system  from  distribution 
bottlenecks and constraints; (ii) enable continued operation and 
maintenance in accordance with best international practices; and 
(iii) commercialize DISCO operations. Specifically, (i) DISCOs will 
adhere to regulatory requirements and comply with the security 
standards; (ii) about 12,000 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of additional 
energy will be supplied through the national grid annually; (iii) the 
system will be capable of meeting peak demand, with electricity 
outages significantly reduced; and (iv) 30 million additional people 
will have access to electricity from the national grid. 
 
Investment Program  The Investment Program is designed to provide grid-connected 
Benefits and  customers with adequate and reliable supply of electricity, which 
Beneficiaries  will support the Government’s objective of 8% gross domestic 
product  (GDP)  growth  per  annum.  Substantial  investments  in 
rehabilitation, augmentation, and expansion of the eight power 
distribution  systems  will  increase  the  reliability  of  supply  to 
residential, agricultural, commercial, and industrial customers in 
Pakistan. A secure and predictable electricity supply will lead to 
social and economic benefits and improve conditions for schools,

vi   
hospitals, and other social services. 
 
Multitranche Financing  The  maximum  financing  amount  available  under  the  MFF  is 
Facility Amount and  $810,000,000. The MFF comprises $800,000,000 from OCR and 
Terms  SDR 6,132,000 from ADF resources. The MFF is designed to 
  finance part of the DISCOs’ investment plan, through individual 
  loans. 
   
Financing from OCR resources will be subject to interest to be 
 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
 
rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. Each OCR loan will have a 
 
repayment period of 20 years, including a grace period of 3 years, 
 
an  interest rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-
 
based lending facility, and such other terms and conditions set 
 
forth in the loan and project agreements.  
 
 
Financing from ADF resources equivalent in SDR to $10 million 
will have an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum during 
the  grace  period,  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter,  and  a 
repayment period of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years. 
 
The Government shall make the proceeds of the loans available 
to each DISCO on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB.  
 
Disbursement  The individual loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
Allocation and Relending  Proceeds from the OCR and ADF loans will be relent from the 
Terms  Government to each DISCO denominated in Pakistan rupees at 
an interest rate and terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB. The 
foreign exchange risk will be borne by the Government. ADB will 
conduct due diligence on the subprojects mentioned in the PFRs, 
to ensure that they comply with the FFA. 
 
Advance Contracting  For  each  subproject  and  for  the  support  component,  advance 
and Retroactive  contracting  for  procurement  of  equipment,  civil  works,  and 
Financing  consulting services will be allowed, subject to these being eligible 
  according  to  agreed  procedures  and  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
Retroactive financing may be available under individual loans for 
expenditures  incurred  12  months  prior  to  the  signing  of  the 
corresponding Loan Agreement, with a ceiling of up to 20% for the 
loan  amount,  according  to  Cost  Sharing  and  Eligibility  of 
Expenditures  for  Asian  Development  Bank  Financing:  A  New 
Approach. The Government and DISCOs have been informed that 
approval of advance contracting and retroactive financing does 
not commit ADB to financing any of the proposed subprojects.  
 
Period of Utilization  The utilization period will be for 10 years from 2008 to 2018, with 
the last PFR to be submitted by end 2014. Each specific loan will

Implementation  Each DISCO will be responsible for the implementation of its own 
Arrangements  investments  and  its  individual  projects  in  line  with  the  Project 
Agreements, and each will be named an implementing agency. 
 
Executing Agency  The  Pakistan  Electric  Power  Company  (PEPCO)  will  be  the 
Executing Agency. Its role will be limited to monitoring the loan 
disbursement,  and  coordination  of  reporting  requirements  and 
other administrative requirements of ADB.  
 
Procurement  Procurement to be financed under the Investment Program will be 
done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  A 
procurement  plan  has been  prepared  for  Tranche-1  to  ensure 
optimum  competition.  The  procurement  plan  will  be  updated 
annually. For each subsequent tranche, a separate procurement 
plan will be prepared. 
 
Consulting Services  Consulting  services  will  be  required  for,  among  others, 
(i) preparation  of  subprojects,  (ii)  detailed  design,  and 
(iii) construction  supervision  and  contract  management,  and 
capacity building of the DISCOs. Consultants will be selected and 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants.  Consulting  firms  will  be  selected  through 
international  competition  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based 
selection  method.  Individual  consultants  may  be  recruited  for 
specific  assignments  in  accordance  with  ADB  procedure.  It  is 
envisioned that, because of the continuation of a number of tasks 
during implementation, single source selection may be used for 
certain assignments with the prior approval of ADB. 
 
Risks and Assumptions  Risks  to  the  Investment  Program  include:  (i)  delays  in  power 
sector  reforms,  (ii)  delays  in  future  tariff  determinations  and 
notifications of rates applicable to each DISCO, (iii) an increase in 
prices of raw materials, (iv) delays in project implementation and 
failure to secure the necessary clearances in time for construction, 
and (v) failure to mobilize the necessary counterpart funds. These 
risks are all assessed to be manageable through risk mitigation 
measures.  
 
The key assumptions underlying the Investment Program are that 
(i) macroeconomic  growth  will  remain  stable;  (ii)  federal  and 
provincial  governments  will  remain  committed  to  power  sector 
reforms and there will be continued progress on policy, regulatory, 
and  institutional  reforms;  and  (iii)  counterpart  funds  will  be 
mobilized  in  a  timely  manner.  Each  of  the  eight  DISCOs  is 
committed  to  expanding  power  supply  within  Pakistan  through 
increased investment in its networks.

1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR POLICY, STRATEGY, AND PERFORMANCE 
A.  Strategic Context 
2.  Pakistan’s  power  sector  faces  tremendous  challenges  in  its  efforts  to  support  the 
Government of Pakistan’s strategy of increasing the electricity supply to its urban and rural 
population  and  of  securing  overall  economic  growth.  The  key  challenges  are  (i)  lack  of 
generation capacity, (ii) increasing constraints in the transmission and distribution systems, 
(iii) weak financial management and sustainability of the sector entities, and (iv) inadequate 
corporate governance structures for the power companies. A detailed assessment of the power 
sector is provided in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
3.  To  support  development  of  the  power  sector  and  to  encourage  private  sector 
participation, the Government has approved power sector policies, strategies, and action plans 
to  (i)  ensure  independent  regulation  of  the  power  sector;  (ii)  complete  the  power  sector 
unbundling of the Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) by establishing four 
generation, one transmission, and eight distribution companies; (iii) begin the power sector 
privatization program; and (iv) evaluate and optimize the fuel sources of the power sector to 
ensure energy security and minimize overall tariff requirements.  
 
4.  Implementation  of  the  Government’s  power  sector  strategy  would  have  three  main 
outcomes: (i) sector reforms to increase efficiencies and effectiveness and to create an enabling 
environment for more private sector participation and investment, (ii) capacity building in all 
sector  organizations,  covering  financial  management,  efficiency  improvement,  the  clean 
development mechanism, and project management; and (iii) completion of large infrastructure 
development projects in generation, transmission, and distribution. 
 
1.  Power Sector Policy Framework 
5.  In 2000, the Government unveiled the “Vision 2025” program and in 2006 the “Vision 
2030”, both stressing accelerated development of new generation facilities, with greater reliance 
placed on indigenous fuel sources—hydropower, thermal generation using local coal reserves 
or local gas supplies, and renewable technologies. The 2002–2004 power policy includes an 
increase in power generation capacity and encompasses private, public, and private-public 
models. The policy continues the underlying theme of Vision 2030 by encouraging the use of 
indigenous  resources,  principally  hydroelectric  power  and  coal.  A  number  of  thermal  and 
hydroelectric projects are currently being processed under the policy. 
 
6.  The power sector restructuring and reform process, developed in various stages and 
through different initiatives, is reflected today in various policies, such as the Power Policy, 
1994; Hydel Policy, 1995; Transmission Line Policy, 1995; Power Policy, 1998; and Power 
Policy, 2002. These were largely designed to attract private sector participation in a newly 
restructured  power  sector.  This  characterization,  at  least  in  terms  of  outright  government 
control, has changed over the last decade, and Pakistan today enjoys significant private sector-

2 
led generation through 21 independent power producers (IPPs), 19 of which were sanctioned 
under the Power Policy 1994, and which together represent in excess of 30% of total generation 
capacity. 
 
2.  Power Sector Strategy 
7.  The Government’s strategy for the power sector has three main intended outcomes: 
(i) sector reforms to create an enabling environment for private sector participation; (ii) more 
capacity development in all sector organizations, including financial management, efficiency 
improvement,  use  of  the  clean  development  mechanism,  and  project  management;  and 
(iii) completion of large infrastructure development projects in generation, transmission, and 
distribution. 
 
8.  The  Government’s  Medium  Term  Development  Framework,  2005–2010  (MTDF) 
envisages an ambitious investment program for the power sector in order to achieve consistent 
8% annual growth in gross domestic product (GDP). The power sector will need to increase its 
capacity to support this growth target and to meet the demand for and consumption of electricity 
implied by such growth. In addition, about 34% of Pakistan’s population has no access to 
electricity from the national grid and the Government is implementing an ambitious plan to 
extend coverage significantly in rural areas. The lack of generation capacity is being addressed 
through  increased  power  generation  projects  that  apply  public-private  partnership  models. 
Constraints in the power transmission network that were expected to result in significant system 
capacity shortfalls and to restrict GDP growth by almost 0.8% in FY2008, are being addressed 
under a targeted Asian Development Bank (ADB) MFF.1 
 
9.  The MTDF contains a medium- and long-term integrated national energy security plan 
for the country. The objectives of the MTDF are to (i) increase power generation; (ii) enhance 
the exploitation and production of oil, gas, and coal resources and to increase the share of coal 
and alternative energy in the energy mix; (iii) optimize the use of indigenous sources and reduce 
dependence on imported sources; and (iv) encourage and facilitate private sector involvement.  
 
10.  The  MTDF  also  sets  out  an  investment  strategy  for  the  power  transmission  and 
distribution sectors. It recognizes that the existing transmission and distribution infrastructure 
and grid stations are overloaded, that they need to be strengthened, and new generation 
projects be commissioned and connected to the national grid. The MTDF also addresses the 
problems of the distribution network, including overloaded substations and high distribution 
losses, and recommends that the network be expanded and efficiency improved. The MTDF 
makes other recommendations, among them to (i) ensure independent regulation of the power 
sector, (ii) unbundle WAPDA and establish and fully operationalize the successor companies, 
and (iii) strengthen the privatization program. The MTDF also specifies the need to further 
strengthen the regulatory role of the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA).  
 
11.  Although the energy sector parameters are spelled out in the MTDF, currently there is a 
lack  of  integrated  energy  planning  to  analyze/plan  a  consolidated  action  plan  to  address 
country’s energy needs in the short, medium, and long terms. To achieve the objectives of 
adequacy and security of energy supplies as well as ensuring long-term viability of the sector, 
the Government aims to adopt an approach based on implementation of integrated energy

3.  Power Sector Road Map 
12.  The power sector is central to the current and future prosperity of Pakistan through the 
supply of low-cost electricity to domestic customers throughout the country2 and by virtue of its 
capacity to stimulate commercial and industrial development. The key challenges of the power 
sector are (i) lack of generation capacity, (ii) increasing constraints in the transmission and 
distribution systems, (iii) weak financial management and sustainability of the sector entities, 
and (iv) inadequate corporate governance structures for the power companies. 
 
13.  The availability of power remains insufficient to meet peak system demand or to provide 
an adequate level of spinning reserve.3 The current installed generation capacity in Pakistan is 
19,550 megawatts (MW), of which 17,395 MW is in the regions formerly covered by WAPDA.

4.  Power Distribution Sector Road Map  
16.  DISCOs receive electric power from NTDC in their respective geographic areas and 
have inherited the distribution assets at operating voltages of 132 kilovolts (kV) and below. With 
this  goes  the  obligation  to  distribute  electricity  and  make  supplies  available  within  their 
geographic boundaries under rules, service conditions, and tariffs laid down by NEPRA.  
 
17.  DISCOs face several challenges, as their power distribution systems (i) do not provide 
complete geographic coverage, (ii) have a shortage of capacity in areas they do cover, and 
(iii) suffer from the consequences of years of inadequate maintenance and underinvestment. 
 
18.  High growth in electricity demand in Pakistan is putting the existing power distribution 
infrastructure  under  severe  stress  and  there  is  a  clear  need  for  investment.  Substantial 
investments  in  rehabilitation,  augmentation,  and  expansion  of  the  eight  power  distribution 
systems  will  increase  the  reliability  of  supply  to  residential,  agricultural,  commercial,  and 
industrial customers in Pakistan. A secure and predictable electricity supply will lead to social 
and economic benefits and improve conditions for schools, hospitals, and other social services. 
This power distribution sector development road map is a comprehensive plan that specifies the 
details  of  system  renovation  and  expansion  to  provide  all  grid-connected  customers  with 
adequate and reliable supply of electricity, which will support the Government’s objective of 8% 
GDP growth per annum.

and high-quality power supply to the rising number of industrial, commercial, agricultural, and

25.  In the short and medium term, ADB will prioritize assistance for economic infrastructure

B.  Power Distribution Sector Overview 
1.  The Power Distribution Companies 
27.  In Pakistan, for the uninitiated power it is evacuated from generation plants first via the 
transmission  system  (kV)  then  via  the  distribution  system  to  the  consumer.  The  power 
distribution system is defined to cover any lines and substations at 132 kV and lower voltages. 
More specifically, the system contains (i) overhead lines at voltages of 132 kV, 66 kV, 33 kV, 
and 11 kV, as well as an extensive low voltage network; and (ii) substations for stated voltage 
levels. The system serves a nationwide customer base, but access to grid connections is 
currently at 66%, resulting in a relatively large requirement for rural electrification.  
 
28.  Under a business transfer agreement implemented on 1 March 1999, the distribution 
system  assets  previously  owned  by  WAPDA  were  vested  in  eight  newly  incorporated 
geographically based DISCOs. Each company took over properties, rights, assets, obligations, 
and liabilities of the distribution system within its geographic area. The eight DISCOs are 
obliged to provide a connection to their distribution systems to all eligible customers as defined 
by NEPRA, and included in license conditions. The DISCOs further have the obligation to 
maintain  the  distribution  system  to  enable  the  effective,  efficient,  and  safe  distribution  of 
electricity  to  customers.  The  obligations  upon  the  DISCOs  are  set  out  in  the  individual

7 
distribution license held by each company, and reinforced by generally applicable requirements 
of the national grid and distribution codes and customer service standards. 
 
29.  The eight DISCOs among them cover the whole of Pakistan, except Karachi, tribal 
areas, and the Northern Areas, each taking its power requirements primarily from NTDC. Each 
DISCO is required by incorporation and by regulatory requirements to (i) maintain and upgrade 
its current system; (ii) plan, design, and implement system expansion; and (iii) operate the 
system  according  to  operational  needs  and  distribution  license  conditions  to  ensure  the 
effective,  reliable,  and  safe  distribution  of  electricity  from  the  supply  points  to  customers’ 
premises across its licensed territory. 
 
30.  In terms of human resources, the transition of staff from WAPDA to the DISCOs has 
been completed. The transfer of assets and liabilities has also been substantially completed. 
Independent  financial  statements  have  been  prepared  and  audited,  in  compliance  with 
distribution license requirements, for independent DISCO operations from FY2004 to FY2006. 
However, the financial independence of the DISCOs has yet to reach the level required of an 
autonomous corporation.  
 
2.  DISCOs’ Performance 
31.  The distribution systems are old and in many cases not built for the capacity now 
demanded. It is known that many transformers are heavily loaded or overloaded. Lack of 
maintenance  of  the  distribution  systems  has  resulted  in  ongoing  deterioration  of  system 
components and increased losses. The performance of the distribution companies does not 
currently comply with the distribution license conditions, in the areas of service standards or the 
technical codes produced by NEPRA. Currently, these standards are not actively enforced by 
NEPRA.  
 
32.  Total DISCOs’ system losses averaged 20% in 2006. The range across the DISCOs is 
from 39% in the worst case to 10% in the best case. In the distribution system, high losses are 
caused by the excess load on the transformers and lines, exacerbated by the poor power factor5 
of the load. Even the highest performing DISCO has scope to address the current situation, and 
one of the stated objectives of this investment facility from all DISCOs is to address system 
losses. The overall distribution system losses are a combination of technical and nontechnical 
losses. The total distribution losses as of 30 June 2006 are shown in Table 2. These losses are 
calculated based on the difference between electricity purchase and electricity sale (both in 
gigawatt-hours [GWh]).

C.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities of the Power Distribution Sector 
1.  Key Problems 
41.  Pakistan’s  power  distribution  sector  faces  three  major  challenges:  (i)  the  system 
reliability  prevents  continuous  supply,  (ii)  high  distribution  losses,  and  (iii)  severe  financial 
shortcomings. The system is unable to meet the current demand, and is already falling behind 
power generation expansion targets. To enable the increased generating capacity to support the 
Government’s economic growth targets, the power distribution system (in addition to the power 
transmission system) must (i) be strengthened to meet current system requirements and fulfill 
demand, and (ii) keep pace with the increasing customer demand. 
 
42.  The power distribution system is negatively impacted by aging, overloading, and poor 
maintenance. It is unreliable, and at times there is load shedding and delivery of supplies 
outside statutory voltage limits. The system needs immediate rehabilitation, augmentation, and 
expansion to meet customer demands and system security requirements. Ensuring the safe and 
reliable distribution of electricity will be a major challenge for Pakistan.  
 
43.  The financial weaknesses affecting the power distribution sector are severely impacting 
the financial sustainability of DISCOs and the power sector in general. The financial shortfall in 
distribution is the primary cause of circular debt problems in Pakistan. There is an urgency to 
resolve the financial weaknesses to ensure (i) elimination of the circular debt, (ii) reduction in 
the  requirements  for  subsidies,  and  (iii)  development  of  financially  sustainable  DISCOs. 
Focusing on the future investment requirements of DISCOs, it would be difficult to secure 
financing if the current financial parameters and procedures continue. 
 
2.  Financial Issues 
44.  The financial sustainability of the power sector is dependent on timely and accurate 
(i) submission of tariff applications by the DISCOs; (ii) execution of the tariff determination by 
NEPRA; (iii) notification of the tariff determination by the Government; (iv) metering, billing, and 
collection by the DISCOs; (v) payment of subsidy allocations by the Government; (vi) payment 
from  DISCOs  to  the  Central  Power  Purchasing  Agency  (CPPA)  for  electricity  purchased;

10 
(vii) payment from DISCOs to NTDC for transmission charges; and (viii) settlement of purchases 
and sale of electricity by CPPA, which has recently been established and is preparing to take up 
this role.  
 
45.  The current regime allows DISCOs to retain only that portion of income that is agreed as 
necessary  to  cover  their  routine  operating  costs  (primarily  salaries).  The  remainder  is 
transferred to WAPDA for onward disbursement to power producers and NTDC. The current 
tariff levels result in shortfall of funds that impact on both the DISCOs and NTDC.  
 
46.  The Government has determined that the single buyer function presently licensed to 
NTDC will be handed to an independent agency, CPPA. Tariff determinations made for CPPA, 
and agreements with generation companies and IPPs, have been revised to reflect CPPA as 
the single buyer. When CPPA comes into effect, it is expected that the DISCOs will achieve a 
further degree of autonomy by the establishment of an escrow account for each DISCO, into 
which all revenues will be paid. CPPA will have first call on each escrow account to settle 
energy purchased accounts, and the balance will be under the control of the DISCO. 
 
47.  Despite the power purchase cost increases, end user electricity tariffs have not been 
increased correspondingly and the DISCOs’ profitability has suffered. During the year ended 
30 June 2006, only one DISCO (Lahore Electric Supply Company [LESCO]) recorded a small 
profit. In February 2007, NEPRA issued determinations on tariff petitions submitted by the 
DISCOS  in  2005.  The  determinations  allowed  significant  tariff  increases  for  all  DISCOs. 
However, all DISCOs appealed against the decisions on the basis that the assumptions used by 
NEPRA in the tariff formula should be adjusted based on current data and plans. Hearings with 
NEPRA were held in May 2007; in each case, NEPRA has reached a determination, but these 
had not been announced at the time of the Appraisal Mission. 
 
48.  In the meantime, the Government has issued a tariff determination that sets out tariffs 
applicable from 24 February 2007 payable by customers. The rates set out are consistent 
across all DISCOs. These rates are lower than those originally determined by NEPRA but the 
notification confirms that the difference between the relevant rates determined by NEPRA and 
the rates charged from customers shall be paid by the Government. The timely payment of 
these  tariff  subsidies  by  the  Government  is  crucial  for  the  financial  independence  of  the 
DISCOs. The Government budgeted PRs57 billion for power sector subsidies in FY2007. 
 
49.  The tariff formula allows a pass-through of power costs (subject to an adjustment for 
allowed losses), recovery of operating and maintenance costs (including depreciation), and a 
return on investment. Under the formula, the DISCOs have the potential to earn reasonable 
profits in the future provided that realistic and achievable assumptions are adopted by NEPRA. 
 
50.  The time lag between raising customer tariffs in line with power purchase costs has 
meant that DISCOs have been unable to pay NTDC for the full cost of power purchased and a 
large outstanding balance remains due. At the year ended 30 June 2006, the total balance due 
from all DISCOs (excluding Karachi Electric Supply Company [KESC]) was PRs128.6 billion. 
This represents a significant financial burden for the sector, which has yet to be resolved. 
 
51.  DISCOs currently have satisfactory accounting capacities and established accredited 
external audit processes in accordance with international audit standards. They have also 
developed  sufficient  in-house  functions  and  systems  to  handle  payments,  billings,  and 
collections. Accounting systems are well developed but continue to rely on significant manual 
processes. Several DISCOs are actively pursuing computerization of accounting systems to

11 
improve control and efficiency in financial management. However, financial management, which 
would benefit from some external assistance in capacity building, is in need of strengthening in 
some DISCOs. 
 
3.  Governance Matters  
52.  As  the  unbundling  transition  period  is  coming  to  an  end  and  DISCOs  are  building 
capacity to enable their independence from WAPDA, the corporate governance structure of their 
boards of directors needs to be in accordance with best international practice. Currently, each 
board  consists  of  a  chair,  three  members  from  the  private  sector,  and  three  officials 
representing the owner, the Government. The nomination of the board members is made by 
chair of Pakistan Electric Power Company (PEPCO) in accordance with a presidential directive. 
A  situation  where  the  same  individual  holds  positions  on  several  boards  of  directors  is 
counterproductive to the Government’s power sector policy and in contradiction with corporate 
governance principles. For example, the chair of NTDC and another director concurrently hold 
seats in WAPDA and PEPCO. There is an inherent conflict of interest if a DISCO board member 
also sits on the board of WAPDA or another company that holds transmission and/or generation 
assets. Such conflicts of interest would make it difficult for individuals to exercise their fiduciary 
duties and carry out their oversight role. 
 
4.  Private Sector Participation 
53.  The Government is acutely aware of the need for private sector participation in the 
power sector. In 2002, it set out a policy for power generation projects that provided a clear set 
of incentives, along with a regulatory regime, to attract private capital. Pakistan has been 
successful  in  attracting  private  sector  investment  and  is  working  to  improve  the  enabling 
environment.7 The 15 commissioned IPPs make up about 4,000 MW of generating capacity.  
  
54.  In line with overall power sector policies, the power distribution subsector promotes 
private sector economic activities by making available power through distribution of electricity 
from the IPPs. A robust distribution system is the anchor for private sector investments in power 
distribution  companies.  Through  substantial  investments  in  the  distribution  system,  the 
Government will be able to establish an environment conducive to private sector investments. At 
the same time, it will remove concerns about the ability to distribute power from IPPs and 
ensure  a  continuous  supply  of  electricity  to  end  customers.  Two  of  the  DISCOs,  namely 
Faisalabad  Electric  Supply  Company  (FESCO)  and  Peshawar  Electric  Supply  Company 
(PESCO), are currently being prepared for privatization by the Privatization Commission. The 
private sector is showing strong interest in the two companies, but is uncomfortable with the 
surrounding environment, as it negatively impacts the operations and financial performance of 
the  companies.  Through  this  MFF,  ADB  will  assist  the  Government  to  strengthen  the 
environment  for  private  sector  investments  in  the  power  sector,  by  (i)  making  further 
improvements  to  the  enabling  conditions  for  power  distribution,  and  (ii) providing  financial 
security for the funding of power distribution facilities that would ensure distribution of electricity 
from IPPs. 
 
55.  The Government is considering additional privatizations in the power distribution sector 
with details to be decided after FESCO has been privatized. In addition to privatization, the

5.  External Assistance 
57.  The major sources of external assistance to the power sector are ADB, the Government 
of Japan, and the World Bank. Together, they provide more than half of the official external 
assistance. ADB has supported both KESC and the Water and Power Development Authority 
(WAPDA),  while  the  World  Bank  has  mainly  provided  assistance  to  WAPDA.  Pakistan’s 
development partners have been working together to evolve a strategy for the privatization of 
the power sector. ADB, the World Bank, and the Government have prepared a policy matrix, 
with a clear delineation of the division of labor between ADB and the World Bank.  
58.  Bilateral  Support.  The  Canadian  International  Development  Agency  has supported 
WAPDA to rehabilitate the Warsak Hydroelectric Power Station. It has also provided assistance 
to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Resources to develop and 
implement sound policies and regulatory frameworks to encourage private sector investment 
and  to  enforce  effective  conservation  and  environmental  regulations.  The  Canadian 
International Development Agency also supports public and private companies to develop and 
manage hydrocarbon resources. The Government of Germany is  supporting a hydropower 
promotion program and a grid station in Ghakkar for power transmission from Ghazi Barotha. 
The Government of Japan is considering assistance for energy efficiency enhancement through 
improvements to the national grid, the load dispatch system, and area-specific electrification. 
 
6.  ADB Operations and Sector Strategy   
59.  ADB Operations. Since the start of ADB operations in Pakistan in 1968, total lending to 
the energy sector in Pakistan amounts to about $4.2 billion, of which $3.6 billion is to the power 
subsector and $0.6 billion to the natural gas and petroleum subsectors. During recent years, 
ADB’s overall lending to the energy sector accounted for about 28% of total lending to Pakistan. 
About three fourths of the assistance to the power subsector ($1,575 million for 13 loans) has 
been provided to WAPDA and the rest to KESC. ADB has been the major source of external 
assistance to the energy sector in Pakistan, having provided about one third of total external 
resources to the sector. ADB’s nonlending activities have also been important in the sector, with 
a total of $16.0 million provided for 30 technical assistance (TA) projects.  
 
60.  Sector Portfolio Description. The energy sector portfolio currently has two MFFs and 
eight  ongoing  TA  projects.  The  two  ongoing  MFFs  in  the  renewable  energy  and  power 
transmission subsectors are in the early stages of implementation and are satisfactory. TA 
implementation performance is generally in line with Pakistan and ADB-wide averages. The 
country operational framework emphasizes the need to strengthen governance and improve on 
portfolio performance, both of which are important in the energy sector. 
 
7.  Lessons  
61.  Ten ADB-financed power projects approved before 1983 have been post-evaluated. All 
were  classified  “generally  successful”.  The  post-evaluation  findings  showed  an  average

13 
implementation delay of 2.4 years (78%). Five of the projects experienced an average cost 
overrun of about 82%, and the other five an underrun of 28%. The post-evaluations drew 
attention  to  the  need  for  an  in-depth  analysis  of  all  technical  issues  before  a  project  is 
formulated,  and  the  need  to  review  cost  estimates  comprehensively  at  appraisal.  The 
performance of ADB-financed projects after 1983 has improved. However, KESC and WAPDA 
have been unable to meet the system loss targets, so they have not been able to comply with 
the financial covenants. ADB loans are listed in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
62.  Tariff adjustments have been based on social equity and affordability considerations, 
which has led to a lack of commercial focus and inhibited KESC and WAPDA from generating 
enough funds to meet all expansion, rehabilitation, and reinforcement requirements. The utilities 
have lacked focused leadership, good management practices, and transparency in operational 
and financial matters. Most ADB-financed projects have been sector loans and more recently 
two MFFs. This allows considerable flexibility in selection of subprojects, and in the use of 
consultants  for  formulating  the  subprojects.  As  a  result,  cost  overruns  have  been  greatly 
reduced. However, slow project implementation remains a problem. Delays have been caused 
by slow procurement of consultants and goods, bureaucratic procedures, organizational and 
institutional weaknesses, changes in project scope, and shortages of qualified staff.  
 
63.  Lessons learned from previous projects are reflected in three specific measures in the 
Investment  Program:  (i)  in-depth  preparation  of  the  subprojects  included  in  each  tranche, 
(ii) early action on procurement and consulting services, and (iii) measurable milestones and 
close implementation facilitation and supervision. To ensure quality at entry, each subproject 
has  been  evaluated  using  five  criteria:  (i)  technical;  (ii)  financial;  (iii) economic; 
(iv) environmental  assessment;  and  (v) social  assessment,  including  land  acquisition  and, 
where necessary, a resettlement plan. Such early attention to procurement will ensure that bid 
document preparation and review procedures do not lead to delays. Close follow-up during 
manufacturing  of  goods,  construction  of  civil  works,  and  installation  should  ensure  timely 
corrective measures where needed and an early completion of each subproject.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
64.  The proposed Investment Program is closely linked to Pakistan’s long-term power sector 
strategy and is an integral part of the power distribution development program. The Investment 
Program will enhance the efficiency of the overall power distribution system and provide an 
adequate  and  reliable  power  supply  to  a  greater  number  of  industrial,  commercial  and 
residential customers. The power sector is a key infrastructure area for economic growth and 
social development, and the Investment Program will be a vital way of strengthening and 
expanding the power sector and supporting economic growth in Pakistan.  
 
B.  Outputs 
65.  The  proposed  Investment  Program  will  (i)  improve  power  distribution  infrastructure 
through rehabilitation, augmentation, and expansion of the secondary (132 kV and 66 kV) 
transmission  network,  and  relieve  the  power  system  from  distribution  bottlenecks  and 
constraints;  and  (ii)  assist  in  commercializing  DISCO  operations.  Specifically,  (i)  about 
12,000 GWh of additional energy will be supplied through the national grid annually; (ii) the 
system will be capable of meeting peak demand, with electricity outages significantly reduced;

14 
(iii)  30  million  additional  people  will  have  access  to  electricity  from  the  national  grid;  and 
(iv) DISCOs will adhere to regulatory requirements and comply with the security standards.  
 
66.  The MMF will finance the proposed Investment Program, comprising subprojects that 
are part of the DISCOs’ investment plan, through individual loans for each tranche. 
 
C.  Investment Program Benefits and Beneficiaries  
67.  The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  provide  grid-connected  customers  with 
adequate and reliable supply of electricity. The rehabilitation, augmentation, and expansion of 
the  eight  power  distribution  systems  will  increase  the  reliability  of  supply  to  residential, 
agricultural, commercial, and industrial customers in Pakistan. A reliable electricity supply will 
lead to social and economic benefits and improved conditions for schools, hospitals, and other 
social services.  
 
D.  Technical Justification and Selection Criteria  
68.  The subprojects under the proposed Investment Program for the eight DISCOs cover the 
whole  country.  The  Investment  Program  is  divided  into  tranches,  with  Tranche-1  covering 
approximately 150 subprojects (Supplementary Appendix C). Some of these subprojects are 
further subdivided into numerous smaller jobs at multisite locations on the distribution systems. 
These subprojects are urgently needed for the system to meet system security reliability and 
safety requirements. The following criteria were used to identify the subprojects: (i) technical 
justification, (ii) financial and economic viability, and (iii) minimal residual environmental and 
social impacts. Some subprojects to address health and safety, operating cost reduction, and 
improved management information are also included. 
 
69.  Each subproject in Tranche-1 has been tested for financial and economic viability, and 
assessed for environmental or social impact. In the case of the sub-transmission subprojects, 
load flow studies by NTDC and the technical merits of subprojects were assessed and the 
feasibility reports presented to ADB. Almost 60% of the value of subprojects proposed for 
Tranche-1 relates to the secondary transmission system, and most of these are additions or 
augmentations  to  transformers  within  existing  substations.  Two  subprojects  deliver  a  new 
substation, with  an  associated  transmission  line  and  power  transformers,  and  four  involve 
construction of transmission lines.  
 
70.  The  benefits  to  be  delivered  from  the  subprojects  in  Tranche-1  include  addition  of 
approximately 2,200 megavolt-amperes (MVA) of transformer capacity, improved the security of 
supply to customers by moving toward compliance with regulatory security standards governing 
planning  and  operation  of  the  sub-transmission  system,  with  reliability  and  availability 
improvements on the lower voltages. 
 
E.  Subproject Preparation, Implementation, and Monitoring Capabilities 
 
71.  The DISCOs are relatively young entities and their capacity is in some cases limited, so 
that they are dependent on external technical service providers (including NTDC) for a number 
of technical service issues, for which they are charged. At an individual level, most of the 
DISCO staff are well motivated to improve the situation, and possess the necessary technical 
skills to identify and prioritize the work required to improve their distribution systems. However, 
in some cases, training in modern distribution planning and utility management in a regulated 
environment, as well as in information and communications technology, is needed to bring the

15 
DISCOs up to date. DISCOs still require adequate project management and implementation 
skills to implement a large loan with multiple location, size, and technology subprojects. 
 
72.  ADB is providing support through the Infrastructure Development loan8 to assist the 
DISCOs in preparing subprojects for Tranche-2. The objective is to establish resources and 
capacity in each DISCO to enable it to become autonomous and expand subproject preparation 
and implementation skills.  
 
73.  In addition, an investment program support component will be provided to help DISCOs 
prepare, implement, and monitor the subprojects under the Investment Program (Appendix 3). It 
will  cover  (i)  power  distribution  subproject  implementation,  including  general  business 
management, portfolio review, project management, and program management; (ii) technical 
operation and maintenance; (iii) accounting, financial, and economic management, and financial 
reporting;  (iv) contracting,  procurement,  and  inventory  management,  (v)  management 
information system and economics of cost recovery and tariff setting; (vi) project development, 
including  policy  development,  feasibility  studies,  site  identification,  and  project  design;  and 
(vii) utility management in a regulated environment.

G.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Executing and Implementing Agencies  
80.  PEPCO, established in 1998, is an agency responsible for managing the power sector 
unbundling process. It has been nominated by MOWP to act as the Executing Agency (EA), 
with each DISCO being the Implementing Agency (IA) for work in its own area. PEPCO’s role in 
the  processing  and  implementation  of  the  Investment  Program  is  that  of  a  coordinator  of 
activities, such as preparation of Planning Commission (PC-1) forms and PFRs, and monitoring 
implementation  activities.  The  DISCOs  are  responsible  for  (i)  selecting  and  preparing  the 
subprojects, (ii) submitting their requirements for inclusion in PC-1 documents to PEPCO, (iii) 
submitting  withdrawal  applications  to  ADB,  and  (iv)  timely  implementation  of  respective 
subprojects.  
 
81.  An implementation consultant will be employed under the Investment Program to assist 
the DISCOs in project implementation, albeit providing different levels of assistance to different 
DISCOs. The implementation consultant will be staffed with international and local experts. The 
implementation consultant will report to PEPCO on administrative issues and to each DISCO on 
operational issues. Each DISCO will establish a project management unit (PMU). The PMU will 
undertake project preparation, implementation, and reporting duties; and will ensure compliance 
with ADB regulations. 
 
2.  Investment Program Management  
82.  The Investment Program will follow MFF implementation procedures. Each DISCO will 
be responsible for preparing its own subprojects, which will be combined into a single multi-
DISCO PFR. Preparation of the combined PFR will be the responsibility of PEPCO, which will 
submit the PFR to ADB through the Economic Affairs Division when (i) the PFR has been 
prepared in accordance with MFF requirements, and (ii) PEPCO has received the required 
government approvals. The DISCOs will make their PFR submissions to PEPCO in a timely 
manner to meet the implementation plan in Appendix 5. Prior to ADB acceptance of a PFR, 
ADB will conduct due diligence to ensure that the Government complies in full with the terms 
and conditions of the FFA.

18 
83.  Each DISCO will prepare quarterly progress reports from the date of loan effectivity 
covering preparation and implementation of each PFR. A combined progress report, covering all 
participating DISCOs, will be compiled by the implementation consultant during its tenure. 
 
3.  Implementation Period 
84.  The Investment Program will be implemented over 10 years, inclusive of procurement 
and  construction  activities,  from  2008  to  2017.  The  subprojects  are  expected  to  have 
implementation periods of 3 years. The last PFR should be submitted not later than the end of 
2014. 
 
4.  Procurement and Consulting Services 
85.  Each DISCO will conduct the procurement of goods and services for its own subprojects. 
Recruitment of the implementation consultant will be conducted by PEPCO. 
 
86.  Procurement of goods and services to be financed under the Investment Program will be 
implemented in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time). International competitive bidding (ICB) will be used for the supply of goods and works 
being funded under the Investment Program. ICB will be used for goods contracts estimated to 
cost  the  equivalent  of  $1  million  or  more,  and  for  works  contracts  estimated  to  cost  the 
equivalent of $5 million or more. A tentative procurement plan for the subprojects to be financed 
under  Tranche-1,  indicating  the  detailed  thresholds  of  each  procurement  method,  is  in 
Appendix 6. The procurement plan will be updated annually to cover the next 18-month period. 
 
87.  Consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Firms  carrying  out  consulting 
services  will  be  selected  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method.  Individual 
consultants will be recruited in accordance with government procedures acceptable to ADB. 
Because of the continuation of a number of tasks during implementation, it is envisioned that 
single source selection may be used for certain assignments with the prior approval of ADB. 
 
5.  Disbursement Arrangements 
88.  A separate Loan Agreement will be established between the Government and ADB for 
each PFR. The Loan Agreement will describe the detailed disbursement arrangements for a 
specified PFR. All loan disbursements will be in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement 
Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time). Imprest accounts will be established for all 
DISCOs, which will be invited to ADB’s loan disbursement seminars conducted in Pakistan. An 
imprest  account  for  the  ADF  loan  will  be  opened  by  PEPCO.  Statement  of  expenditure 
procedures will be used to reimburse eligible expenditures for any individual payment under 
$100,000 for the OCR loan and $50,000 for the ADF loan. 
 
6.  Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing  
89.  Because of the urgent nature of the subprojects, the Government and the DISCOs have

C.  Economic Analysis 
102.  The  proposed  investments  to  be  funded  by  ADB  are  part  of  Pakistan’s  integrated 
generation, transmission, and distribution expansion program; and an integral component of the 
transmission and distribution system development plan prepared based on NTDC load forecast 
using  least-cost  planning  principles.  The  economic  analysis  was  based  on  a  “time-slice” 
approach to the distribution sector development plan, as individual subprojects are not stand-
alone  investments  and  would  not  yield  all  their  benefits  if  considered  in  isolation.  The 
Investment Program will ease chronic supply shortages and help meet the projected growth in 
demand for electric power. Demand forecasts and cost-benefit projections were prepared and 
analyzed and the Investment Program was judged to be economically viable. A summary of the 
economic analysis is in Appendix 9.  
 
103.  The main benefits stem from (i) allowing for system expansion to meet load growth; 
(ii) improving efficiency, reliability, and system security; and (iii) reducing losses. The physical 
output—rehabilitated, augmented, and expanded distribution infrastructure—will add to existing 
supply (incremental benefits).  
 
104.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was estimated to be 23%, based on the 
incremental  cost-benefit  streams  associated  with  the  proposed  investments.  Economic 
performance  was  evaluated  by  comparing  with-  and  without-project  scenarios.  The  EIRR 
compares the annual streams of economic capital and operating costs against benefits, based 
on willingness-to-pay. All costs, benefits, and revenues are expressed in 2007 constant prices. 
The analysis period includes the construction period and 30 years of operation. Economic 
benefits  accrue  to  customers  and  the  economy  as  a  result  of  the  Investment  Program. 
Incremental consumption occurs because of the extended availability of adequate and reliable 
power supplies. The economic feasibility of the proposed subprojects in Tranche-1 has been 
tested by establishing the need for the subprojects, and establishing that they represent the 
least-cost means of achieving their objectives. The analysis results in an EIRR of 30%, justifying 
the viability of Tranche-1 investment.

F.  Poverty Assessment  
112.  The overall strategy of the Investment Program is to address bottlenecks to economic 
growth  and  the  delivery  of  high  quality  supply  of  electricity  to  the  unserved  population 
(Appendix 11). The Investment Program will benefit grid-connected customers with adequate 
and reliable supply of electricity, which would support the projections for growth in energy 
demand  and  the  Government’s  confirmed  intent  to  make  affordable  grid-based  electricity 
supplies available to the entire population through the Village Electrification Program. The 
beneficiaries will be the population residing in unserved areas, and existing customers receiving 
improved quality of supply. These areas are currently not benefiting from subsidized electricity 
tariffs, but are indirectly paying for them in terms of taxes, forgone access to electricity, or other 
forgone investments. A secure and predictable electricity supply will enable social and economic 
benefits to materialize. Poor and vulnerable customers—including hospitals, schools, and other 
social utilities—are often hardest hit by inadequate power supply, load shedding, and poor 
power quality. They will also benefit directly from the investments.  
 
113.  Improvements  in  quality  and  reliability  of  supply  that  will  accrue  from  targeted 
investments are expected to improve living conditions in the rural areas through the creation of 
job and income opportunities. Businesses as well as farmers are expected to increase their 
productivity.  Demand  for  electric  installations,  supplies,  and  maintenance  is  expected  to 
increase, creating further new job opportunities. In addition, a reliable electricity supply improves 
households’ quality of life, especially for women who are traditionally responsible for activities 
inside the house. A comprehensive poverty impact assessment for the Investment Program is 
being  prepared.  The  preliminary  data  show  that  unserved  areas  are  among  the  most 
economically deprived, with the highest proportion of poor people in Pakistan.  
 
G.  Potential Risks and Assumptions  
114.  Key  assumptions  are  (i)  macroeconomic  growth  will  remain  stable;  (ii)  federal  and 
provincial  governments  will  remain  committed  to  power  sector  reforms  and  there  will  be 
continued progress on policy, regulatory, and institutional reforms; and (iii) counterpart funds will 
be mobilized in a timely manner. 
 
115.  Risks to the Investment Program include (i) delays in power sector reforms, both in tariff 
determinations and in notifications of the rates applicable to the distribution companies by 
NEPRA  and  the  Government;  (ii)  delays  in  tariff  determinations  and  notifications  of  rates 
applicable  for  NTDC’s  wheeling  charges  by  NEPRA  and  the  Government,  to  facilitate 
investments  in  power  transmission  facilities;  (iii)  lack  of  and  untimely  payment  by  the 
Government of subsidies to DISCOs; (iv) increases in prices of cement, steel, fuel, and other 
raw materials that would render the Investment Program financially nonviable; (v) delays in 
subproject implementation; (vi) failure to complete environmental and social assessments and 
to  actively  pursue  and  secure  environmental  clearances  for  all  subprojects  before 
commencement of construction; and (vii) failure to mobilize the necessary counterpart funds. 
These risks all appear low: DISCOs are committed to expanding power supply within Pakistan 
through  increased  investments  in  distribution  facilities.  The  lack  of  capacity  in  DISCOs  to 
facilitate environmental and resettlement compliance is a concern, but this can be mitigated by

25 
making dedicated resources and staffing a requirement of the loan, as specified in the FFA. 
Risk analyses will be expanded to include sensitivity analyses at a later stage of Investment 
Program processing.  
 
116.  Specific assumptions for the subprojects under the Tranche-1 are: (i) counterpart funds 
will be made available in a timely manner; (ii) there will be no delay in the notification of 
distribution company tariffs; and (iii) CPPA will be established and empowered in a timely 
fashion, since without it, the financial viability of DISCOs and NTDC cannot be ensured. The 
risks are: (i) there will be a delay in recruitment of consultants and in procurement of contracts in

cement, steel, fuel, and other raw materials, will increase, possibly making the subprojects 
financially  nonviable.  Contingency  funds  will  be  allocated  to  respond  to  any  unforeseen 
changes.

POWER DISTRIBUTION SECTOR ROAD MAP AND INVESTMENT PLAN 
 
A.  Rationale  
1.  The power sector is central to the current and future prosperity of Pakistan through the 
supply of low-cost electricity to domestic customers throughout the country and by virtue of its 
capacity to stimulate commercial and industrial development. The key challenges of the power 
sector are (i) lack of generation capacity, (ii) increasing constraints in the transmission and 
distribution systems, (iii) weak financial management and sustainability of the sector entities, 
and (iv) inadequate corporate governance structures for the power companies. 
   
2.  According to government estimates, electricity demand in Pakistan is forecasted to grow 
by at least 8% a year during 2005–2015. To meet this increasing demand, it is estimated that 
Pakistan will require an additional 2,000 megawatts (MW) annually, which will need to fed 
through  the  distribution  system.  The  Medium  Term  Development  Framework,  2005–2010 
(MTDF) spells out the Government’s energy sector strategy, including investments in power 
generation, transmission, and distribution. Based on the MTDF, the Government developed a 
long-term power generation plan. This identified the demand for increased generation capacity, 
and addressed the size and timing of the commissioning of the new plants. The overall power 
transmission strategy is to ensure that the electricity from the new power generation plants is 
evacuated to the load centers.  
 
3.  The  effective  evacuation  of  power  from  all  the  existing  generating  stations,  and 
connection of the stations to be commissioned in future, is vested in the National Transmission 
and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC).  In  coordination  with  the  Ministry  of  Water  and  Power 
(MOWP),  NTDC  prepared  the  power  transmission  sector  road  map  and  corresponding 
investment plans. In 2006, at the request of the Government, ADB agreed to long-term financing 
support of the power transmission subsector through a multitranche financing facility (MFF) to 
NTDC to realize the investment needs. The power transmission investment subprojects are 
currently  under  implementation.  These  developments  together  address  the  generation  and 
primary  transmission  of  electric  power  to  the  eight  geographically  split  power  distribution 
companies (DISCOs). 
 
4.  DISCOs receive electric power from NTDC in their respective geographic areas and 
have inherited the distribution assets at operating voltages of 132 kilovolt (kV) and below. With 
this  goes  the  obligation  to  distribute  electricity  and  make  supplies  available  within  their 
geographic boundaries under rules, service conditions, and tariffs laid down by the National 
Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA).  
 
5.  DISCOs face several challenges as their power distribution systems (i) do not provide 
complete geographic coverage, (ii) have a shortage of capacity in areas they do cover, and 
(iii) suffer from the consequences of years of inadequate maintenance and underinvestment. 
 
6.  High growth in electricity demand in Pakistan is putting the existing power distribution 
infrastructure  under  severe  stress  and  there  is  a  clear  need  for  investment.  Substantial 
investments  in  rehabilitation,  augmentation,  and  expansion  of  the  eight  power  distribution 
systems  will  increase  the  reliability  of  supply  to  residential,  agricultural,  commercial,  and 
industrial customers in Pakistan. A secure and predictable electricity supply will lead to social 
and economic benefits and improve conditions for schools, hospitals, and other social services. 
This power distribution sector development road map is a comprehensive plan that specifies the 
details  of  system  renovation  and  expansion  to  provide  all  grid-connected  customers  with

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The financial analysis of the proposed subprojects under Tranche 1 has been carried out 
in accordance with Financial Management and Analysis of Projects of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB).1 All financial costs and benefits are expressed in real terms on an after-tax basis in 
Pakistan  rupees.  Capital  costs  were  derived  from  local  sources,  including  5%  physical 
contingencies with the exclusion of price contingencies and interest during implementation for 
capital cost estimation. Financial viability was examined by comparing the incremental costs 
and benefits of with- and without-investment scenarios.  
 
B.  Assumptions 
  
2.  The  subproject  financial  internal  rates  of  return  (FIRRs)  were  calculated  for  three 
components:  (i)  secondary  transmission  grid  (STG),  (ii)  distribution  of  power  (DOP),  and 
(iii) installation  of  capacitors.  These  subproject  FIRRs  were  aggregated  at  the  distribution 
company (DISCO) level and for the overall project.  
 
3.  For the STG component, incremental benefits arise from the increased evacuation of 
power  through  the  distribution  system  because  of  additional  transformer  capacity.  The 
incremental demand was translated into incremental sales using DISCO-specific load factors, 
power factors, and projected growth in demand. The distribution margin, using the National 
Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) methodology to fulfill the DISCO annual revenue 
requirement, was used to convert the incremental energy into monetary terms. The “first circuit 
out” benefit arises as a result of investment in a second circuit with the ability to service demand 
in the event the first one fails. This was valued at the distribution margin on the assumption of a 
1% probability. The loss reduction benefit was valued at the power purchase price to reflect the 
need for lower energy purchase to serve demand.  
 
4.  For the analysis, projected demand growth rates of 6–8% per annum and load factors of 
55–62%  were  used,  depending  on  the  DISCO.  Power  purchase  price  rates  ranging  from 
PRs3.49 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) to PRs3.86/kWh were used. Actual losses at both 132 kilovolts 
(kV) and 11 kV of 9.9–34.2% were used to determine the effective tariff and the distribution 
margin, independent of generating capacity.  
 
5.  DOP components involve the extension of 11 kV distribution networks and installing 
additional distribution transformers to make electricity grid connections available to additional 
customers, primarily in rural areas. FIRRs were developed using a generic model, as it is not 
possible at this stage to identify the precise locations of all of these schemes. The generic 
model involves a 10-kilometer extension of the 11 kV line, connecting a remote village with the

line  (each  transformer  with  a  0.4  kV  network  connecting  10  new  customers)  so  30  new 
customers will be connected. Variations on this scheme will depend on the distance from the 
proposed customers’ locations to the nearest existing 11 kV line, the number of customers to be 
connected, and the collective demand in kilowatts (kW) of those customers. The FIRR assumed 
that 30 new customers would consume 2,000 kWh of electricity annually. This incremental 
benefit was valued at the average distribution margin after adjusting for losses for each DISCO.

C.  Tariff Methodology    
 
7.  The procedure for tariff petition and methodology used in the tariff determination by 
NEPRA is as follows. DISCOs make a petition for revision of tariff to NEPRA. After receipt of the 
application, NEPRA notifies the stakeholders and the public of the most important features of 
the  petition  through  publication  in  a  local  newspaper.  NEPRA  receives  comments  and 
interventions from stakeholders and gives DISCOs a chance to respond before making its 
determination. The tariff becomes effective after a government notification in the official gazette. 
This tariff will remain effective until the next petition by DISCOs, determination by NEPRA, and 
notification by the Government. 
 
8.  In the last determination by NEPRA, the tariff was based on the power purchase price 
(dependent on the generation mix and fuel price), which is a pass-through cost to the customer 
and adjusted for line losses. NEPRA allowed the addition of a distribution margin, which was 
based on an annual revenue requirement for O&M, administration, depreciation, income tax and 
a return on assets, and net of other income. The return on assets was based on the regulatory 
asset base, comprising the average net fixed assets and capital work in progress, and reduced 
by the extent of deferred credit and other income. The rate of return was based on NEPRA’s 
assessment of each DISCO’s weighted average cost of capital (WACC). The cost of debt was 
based on the actual cost of existing borrowings. The rationale of determination of the cost of 
equity has not been stated, while the actual debt-to-equity ratios for each DISCO were used.  
 
D.  Weighted Average Cost of Capital  
 
9.  For estimating the WACC, it is assumed that ADB will finance 74% of overall project 
costs through Tranche-1. It is expected that the Government will relend the funds to DISCOs in

(substantially lower than 17% per annum, as stated in the 1996 government circular). Foreign 
exchange risk will not be borne by DISCOs. The balance will be financed through self-generated 
funds (equity). Fifteen percent is assumed for nominal cost under equity contribution, consistent 
with the rate of return allowed for DISCOs. Domestic inflation is assumed to be 7.5% per 
annum. The WACC is estimated at 10% (Table A8.1). Tax benefits on interest were not taken

12.  Regulatory  risk  is  low  since  there  is  a  functioning  independent  NEPRA  for  tariff

revision of the tariff. Delays in tariff filing by DISCOs, tariff determination by NEPRA, and tariff

management by each party concerned. The tariff determined by NEPRA is never fully recovered 
from customers by DISCOs because of a lower government mandated tariff. The difference is 
reimbursed by the Government through a subsidy payment, but it is often not on a regular basis, 
placing the DISCOs in cash flow difficulties. This poses risks to the Project that are outside the 
DISCOs’ direct control. The Government has taken measures to pay subsidy liabilities to each 
DISCO on time. The fundamental structure of fund flow that allows DISCOs direct control of 
customer  collections  instead  of  remittances  through  the  Water  and  Power  Development 
Authority (WAPDA) is in the process of reform.

investments and their geographical spread lessen the risk of a significant number of projects

D.  Economic Analysis 
1.  Least-Cost Analysis 
8.  Investments at the power distribution system level are based on immediate needs where 
transformers are being augmented and replaced because of existing transformers approaching 
100% capacity. Given rapid load growth, it is not expected that these investments will be 
demonstrated as suboptimal in the future. At an individual feeder level, load flow analyses are 
undertaken to support system improvement investment decisions and to select the least-cost 
options. While these investments are not analyzed in the context of the overall DISCO network, 
the additions can be said to be least cost in the immediate area being examined. Given rapid 
demand growth, it is unlikely that these investments will become suboptimal in the future.  
 
2.  Cost-Benefit Analysis 
9.  The EIRR calculation was based on incremental cost and benefit streams associated 
with each tranche of investment. Economic performance was evaluated by comparing with- and 
without-project scenarios. Incremental consumption occurs because of the extended availability 
of grid-sourced electricity. Economic benefits accrue to customers and the economy as a result 
of the investments.  
 
10.  The main benefits stem from (i) allowing for system expansion to meet load growth; 
(ii) improving efficiency, reliability, and system security; and (iii) reducing losses. The physical 
output—rehabilitated, augmented, and expanded distribution infrastructure—will add to existing 
supply (incremental benefit) and will be substitute for alternative forms of energy supply. The 
incremental benefits were valued for each category of customer, using customers’ willingness-
to-pay for electricity.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Major interventions in the energy sector are designed to achieve economic progress through infrastructure development. Both 
physical investment support and sector reform are necessary so that the benefits from economic growth will accrue to the 
poor.  
By strengthening and expanding distribution capacity, the proposed Investment Program is expected to result in quality and 
reliable delivery of services to customers, particularly benefiting commercial, residential, and agricultural customers in 
Pakistan.  
Poor and vulnerable customers, including social utilities such as hospitals and schools, are often the hardest hit by 
inadequate power supply, load shedding, and poor power quality. They will benefit directly from the subprojects. Direct 
positive economic and social benefits will result from the Investment Program.  
A positive, direct impact on local labor is expected during implementation and an indirect impact will be due to the increased 
income-earning opportunities generated by increased access to electricity and job opportunities during construction. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
Project preparatory technical assistance consultants have prepared a social impact assessment and a poverty impact 
assessment. A socioeconomic survey was undertaken to provide a basis for the assessments. The primary objective of this 
study is to (i) assess whether the benefits of the Project will flow primarily to poor/nonpoor customers; (ii) design the poverty 
intervention component of the Project; and (iii) identify and deal effectively with any social risks such as involuntary 
resettlement, gender, labor, affordability, including the need to prepare any mitigating measures or plans. 
Most poor people in Pakistan are wage laborers or are self-employed. Over 40% of them live close to the poverty line; this 
indicates that shocks, such as illness, death, or drought, have the potential to drive large numbers into poverty. Most are 
landless and less likely to have access to a health clinic or to send their children to school than those with higher incomes. A 
disruption of their daily routine makes them more vulnerable than other groups as they do not have the resources to insure 
against such disruptions. 
The Investment Program is expected to create new full-time employment opportunities in civil works. Improved power supplies 
will induce light industrial and commercial activity, creating employment and improving the productivity and quality of outputs 
in manufacturing and agriculture sectors.   
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
The Investment Program will benefit all grid-connected customers with adequate and reliable supply of electricity, which would 
support the projections for growth in energy demand and the Government’s confirmed intent to make affordable grid-based 
electricity supplies available to the entire population through the village electrification program. A secure and predictable 
electricity supply will enable social and economic benefits to materialize. Poor and vulnerable customers, including hospitals, 
schools, and other social utilities, are often hardest hit by inadequate power supply, load shedding, and poor power quality. 
They will benefit directly from the investments. 
Improvements in the quality and reliability of supply that will accrue from targeted investments are expected to improve living 
conditions in the rural areas through the creation of job and income opportunities. Businesses as well as farmers are expected 
to increase their productivity. Demand for electric installations, supplies, and maintenance is expected to increase, creating
